lines.value: My love shall hear the music of my hounds.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Uncouple in the western valley; let them go:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: We will, fair queen, up to the mountain's top,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And mark the musical confusion
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Of hounds and echo in conjunction.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: HIPPOLYTA
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once,
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: When in a wood of Crete they bay'd the bear
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: With hounds of Sparta: never did I hear
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: Such gallant chiding: for, besides the groves,
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: The skies, the fountains, every region near
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: Seem'd all one mutual cry: I never heard
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: So flew'd, so sanded, and their heads are hung
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: With ears that sweep away the morning dew;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Crook-knee'd, and dew-lapp'd like Thessalian bulls;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Slow in pursuit, but match'd in mouth like bells,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Each under each. A cry more tuneable
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Was never holla'd to, nor cheer'd with horn,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Judge when you hear. But, soft! what nymphs are these?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: EGEUS
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: My lord, this is my daughter here asleep;
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: And this, Lysander; this Demetrius is;
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: This Helena, old Nedar's Helena:
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: I wonder of their being here together.
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: No doubt they rose up early to observe
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The rite of May, and hearing our intent,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Came here in grace our solemnity.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: But speak, Egeus; is not this the day
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That Hermia should give answer of her choice?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: EGEUS
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: It is, my lord.
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Begin these wood-birds but to couple now?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: LYSANDER
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: Pardon, my lord.
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: I pray you all, stand up.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: I know you two are rival enemies:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: How comes this gentle concord in the world,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That hatred is so far from jealousy,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: To sleep by hate, and fear no enmity?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: LYSANDER
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: My lord, I shall reply amazedly,
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: Half sleep, half waking: but as yet, I swear,
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: I cannot truly say how I came here;
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: But, as I think,--for truly would I speak,
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: And now do I bethink me, so it is,--
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: I came with Hermia hither: our intent
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: Was to be gone from Athens, where we might,
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: Without the peril of the Athenian law.
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: EGEUS
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: Enough, enough, my lord; you have enough:
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: I beg the law, the law, upon his head.
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: They would have stolen away; they would, Demetrius,
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: Thereby to have defeated you and me,
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: You of your wife and me of my consent,
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: Of my consent that she should be your wife.
lines.speaker: EGEUS

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Of this their purpose hither to this wood;
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And I in fury hither follow'd them,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Fair Helena in fancy following me.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: But, my good lord, I wot not by what power,--
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: But by some power it is,--my love to Hermia,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Melted as the snow, seems to me now
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: As the remembrance of an idle gaud
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Which in my childhood I did dote upon;
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: The object and the pleasure of mine eye,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Is only Helena. To her, my lord,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Was I betroth'd ere I saw Hermia:
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: But, like in sickness, did I loathe this food;
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: But, as in health, come to my natural taste,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Now I do wish it, love it, long for it,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And will for evermore be true to it.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Egeus, I will overbear your will;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: For in the temple by and by with us
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: These couples shall eternally be knit:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And, for the morning now is something worn,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Our purposed hunting shall be set aside.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Away with us to Athens; three and three,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: We'll hold a feast in great solemnity.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Come, Hippolyta.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: These things seem small and undistinguishable,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: HERMIA
lines.speaker: HERMIA

lines.value: Methinks I see these things with parted eye,
lines.speaker: HERMIA

lines.value: When every thing seems double.
lines.speaker: HERMIA

lines.value: HELENA
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: So methinks:
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: And I have found Demetrius like a jewel,
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: Mine own, and not mine own.
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Are you sure
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: That we are awake? It seems to me
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: That yet we sleep, we dream. Do not you think
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: The duke was here, and bid us follow him?
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: HERMIA
lines.speaker: HERMIA

lines.value: Yea; and my father.
lines.speaker: HERMIA

lines.value: HELENA
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: And Hippolyta.
lines.speaker: HELENA

lines.value: LYSANDER
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: And he did bid us follow to the temple.
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Why, then, we are awake: let's follow him
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And by the way let us recount our dreams.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: BOTTOM
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: [Awaking]  When my cue comes, call me, and I will
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: answer: my next is, 'Most fair Pyramus.' Heigh-ho!
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: Peter Quince! Flute, the bellows-mender! Snout,
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: the tinker! Starveling! God's my life, stolen
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: hence, and left me asleep! I have had a most rare
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: vision. I have had a dream, past the wit of man to
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: say what dream it was: man is but an ass, if he go
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: about to expound this dream. Methought I was--there
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: is no man can tell what. Methought I was,--and
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: methought I had,--but man is but a patched fool, if
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: he will offer to say what methought I had. The eye
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: was. I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: this dream: it shall be called Bottom's Dream,
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: because it hath no bottom; and I will sing it in the
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: latter end of a play, before the duke:
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: sing it at her death.
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: QUINCE
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: Have you sent to Bottom's house ? is he come home yet?
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: STARVELING
lines.speaker: STARVELING

lines.value: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is
lines.speaker: STARVELING

lines.value: transported.
lines.speaker: STARVELING

lines.value: FLUTE

lines.value: If he come not, then the play is marred: it goes
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: not forward, doth it?
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: QUINCE
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: It is not possible: you have not a man in all
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: FLUTE
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: man in Athens.
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: QUINCE
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: Yea and the best person too; and he is a very
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: paramour for a sweet voice.
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: FLUTE
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: You must say 'paragon:' a paramour is, God bless us,
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: a thing of naught.
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: SNUG
lines.speaker: SNUG

lines.value: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and
lines.speaker: SNUG

lines.value: there is two or three lords and ladies more married:
lines.speaker: SNUG

lines.value: if our sport had gone forward, we had all been made
lines.speaker: SNUG

lines.value: men.
lines.speaker: SNUG

lines.value: FLUTE
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: day during his life; he could not have 'scaped
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: sixpence a day: an the duke had not given him
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll be hanged;
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: he would have deserved it: sixpence a day in
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: Pyramus, or nothing.
lines.speaker: FLUTE

lines.value: BOTTOM
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: Where are these lads? where are these hearts?
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: QUINCE
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: BOTTOM
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: Masters, I am to discourse wonders: but ask me not
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: what; for if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: will tell you every thing, right as it fell out.
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: QUINCE
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.
lines.speaker: QUINCE

lines.value: BOTTOM
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is, that
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: the duke hath dined. Get your apparel together,
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: pumps; meet presently at the palace; every man look
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: o'er his part; for the short and the long is, our
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: play is preferred. In any case, let Thisby have
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: clean linen; and let not him that plays the lion
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: pair his nails, for they shall hang out for the
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: lion's claws. And, most dear actors, eat no onions
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath; and I
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: do not doubt but to hear them say, it is a sweet
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: comedy. No more words: away! go, away!
lines.speaker: BOTTOM

lines.value: HIPPOLYTA
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: 'Tis strange my Theseus, that these
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: lovers speak of.
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: More strange than true: I never may believe
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: These antique fables, nor these fairy toys.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: More than cool reason ever comprehends.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The lunatic, the lover and the poet
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Are of imagination all compact:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: One sees more devils than vast hell can hold,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That is, the madman: the lover, all as frantic,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Sees Helen's beauty in a brow of Egypt:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The poet's eye, in fine frenzy rolling,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And as imagination bodies forth
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: A local habitation and a name.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Such tricks hath strong imagination,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That if it would but apprehend some joy,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: It comprehends some bringer of that joy;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Or in the night, imagining some fear,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: How easy is a bush supposed a bear!
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: HIPPOLYTA
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: But all the story of the night told over,
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: And all their minds transfigured so together,
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: More witnesseth than fancy's images
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: And grows to something of great constancy;
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Joy, gentle friends! joy and fresh days of love
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Accompany your hearts!
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: LYSANDER
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: More than to us
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!
lines.speaker: LYSANDER

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Come now; what masques, what dances shall we have,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: To wear away this long age of three hours
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Between our after-supper and bed-time?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Where is our usual manager of mirth?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: What revels are in hand? Is there no play,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Call Philostrate.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: PHILOSTRATE
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Here, mighty Theseus.
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Say, what abridgement have you for this evening?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: What masque? what music? How shall we beguile
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The lazy time, if not with some delight?

lines.value: PHILOSTRATE
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: There is a brief how many sports are ripe:
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Make choice of which your highness will see first.

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: [Reads]  'The battle with the Centaurs, to be sung

lines.value: By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.'
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: We'll none of that: that have I told my love,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: In glory of my kinsman Hercules.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: 'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.'
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That is an old device; and it was play'd
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: When I from Thebes came last a conqueror.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: 'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Of Learning, late deceased in beggary.'
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That is some satire, keen and critical,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: 'A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And his love Thisbe; very tragical mirth.'
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Merry and tragical! tedious and brief!
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: That is, hot ice and wondrous strange snow.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: How shall we find the concord of this discord?
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: PHILOSTRATE
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Which is as brief as I have known a play;
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: But by ten words, my lord, it is too long,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Which makes it tedious; for in all the play
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: There is not one word apt, one player fitted:
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: And tragical, my noble lord, it is;
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Made mine eyes water; but more merry tears
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: What are they that do play it?

lines.value: PHILOSTRATE
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Which never labour'd in their minds till now,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: With this same play, against your nuptial.
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And we will hear it.

lines.value: PHILOSTRATE
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: No, my noble lord;
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: It is not for you: I have heard it over,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: And it is nothing, nothing in the world;
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Unless you can find sport in their intents,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: Extremely stretch'd and conn'd with cruel pain,
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: To do you service.
lines.speaker: PHILOSTRATE

lines.value: THESEUS

lines.value: I will hear that play;

lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged

lines.value: And duty in his service perishing.

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.

lines.value: HIPPOLYTA
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: He says they can do nothing in this kind.
lines.speaker: HIPPOLYTA

lines.value: THESEUS
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Our sport shall be to take what they mistake:
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Takes it in might, not merit.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Where I have come, great clerks have purposed
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: To greet me with premeditated welcomes;
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Make periods in the midst of sentences,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Throttle their practised accent in their fears
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: And in conclusion dumbly have broke off,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, sweet,

lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: As much as we this night have overwatch'd.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: The heavy gait of night. Sweet friends, to bed.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: A fortnight hold we this solemnity,
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: In nightly revels and new jollity.
lines.speaker: THESEUS

lines.value: PUCK
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Now the hungry lion roars,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: And the wolf behowls the moon;
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Whilst the heavy ploughman snores,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: All with weary task fordone.
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Now the wasted brands do glow,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Puts the wretch that lies in woe
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: In remembrance of a shroud.
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Now it is the time of night
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: That the graves all gaping wide,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Every one lets forth his sprite,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: In the church-way paths to glide:
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: And we fairies, that do run
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: By the triple Hecate's team,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: From the presence of the sun,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Following darkness like a dream,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Now are frolic: not a mouse
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Shall disturb this hallow'd house:
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: I am sent with broom before,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: To sweep the dust behind the door.
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: OBERON
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Through the house give gathering light,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: By the dead and drowsy fire:
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Every elf and fairy sprite
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Hop as light as bird from brier;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: And this ditty, after me,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Sing, and dance it trippingly.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: TITANIA
lines.speaker: TITANIA

lines.value: First, rehearse your song by rote
lines.speaker: TITANIA

lines.value: To each word a warbling note:
lines.speaker: TITANIA

lines.value: Hand in hand, with fairy grace,
lines.speaker: TITANIA

lines.value: Will we sing, and bless this place.
lines.speaker: TITANIA

lines.value: OBERON
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Now, until the break of day,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Through this house each fairy stray.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: To the best bride-bed will we,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Which by us shall blessed be;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: And the issue there create
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Ever shall be fortunate.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: So shall all the couples three
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Ever true in loving be;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: And the blots of Nature's hand
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Shall not in their issue stand;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Never mole, hare lip, nor scar,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Nor mark prodigious, such as are
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Despised in nativity,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Shall upon their children be.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: With this field-dew consecrate,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Every fairy take his gait;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: And each several chamber bless,
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Through this palace, with sweet peace;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: And the owner of it blest
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Ever shall in safety rest.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Trip away; make no stay;
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: Meet me all by break of day.
lines.speaker: OBERON

lines.value: PUCK
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: If we shadows have offended,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Think but this, and all is mended,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: That you have but slumber'd here
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: While these visions did appear.
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: And this weak and idle theme,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: No more yielding but a dream,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Gentles, do not reprehend:
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: if you pardon, we will mend:
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: And, as I am an honest Puck,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: If we have unearned luck
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: We will make amends ere long;
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Else the Puck a liar call;
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: So, good night unto you all.
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: Give me your hands, if we be friends,
lines.speaker: PUCK

lines.value: And Robin shall restore amends.
lines.speaker: PUCK
